awd_titl_txt: First Steps Towards a New High Resolution Proxy for Paleomagnetic Field Instabilities:  Tritiogenic 3He Archived in Speleothems
awd_abstract_narration:
The terrestrial magnetic field is critical to life on Earth because it shields the planet from harmful cosmic radiation. It also protects technological infrastructure from damage from solar storms. The Earth's magnetic field is generated by organized motions of liquid iron in the Earth's outer core - the geodynamo - by processes that are not fully understood. Key observable features that can be used to inform models of the geodynamo include magnetic field strength and orientation, both of which change over geologic time. Existing records of the temporal variation of magnetic field strength are incomplete and potentially compromised by secondary processes. A potential new archive originates from the protective nature of the field. Cosmic rays continually strike the atmosphere, but their flux is modulated by the magnetic field. Stronger magnetic fields provide greater deflection of cosmic rays from Earth, and weaker fields provide less deflection. The flux of cosmic rays in turn controls the production rate of cosmogenic nuclides - rare isotopes produced when cosmic rays collide with gases in the atmosphere. Several cosmogenic nuclide archives have already been used to establish the history of magnetic field strength. This project will take exploratory steps towards development of a new high temporal resolution archive: the abundance of tritium - a cosmogenic nuclide with a half-life of 12 years - in fluid inclusions trapped in cave deposits of various ages. As an isotope of hydrogen, the post-production behavior of tritium will be controlled by the atmospheric water cycle, and will not suffer the same complications as previously measured cosmogenic nuclide archives of magnetic field strength.

The decay product of tritium (3He) will be measured in water pockets that are trapped by stalagmites as they grow. The working hypothesis is that these water inclusions take in tritium in proportion to its production by cosmic rays in the atmosphere via the delivery of local rainwater into the cave system. After entrapment, tritium decays to 3He, which is thereafter retained in the water inclusion until analysis. Stalagmites often have annual bands, and can be dated accurately using U/Th geochronology. Taken together, these ideas suggest stalagmites offer a potential record of geomagnetic field changes with better temporal detail than those provided by alternative methods and with independent sources of potential error. This project will take the first steps for creating such a record by developing the necessary analytical methods and then by analyzing stalagmites that captured atmospheric tritium created by nuclear weapons testing in the latter half of the 20th century to confirm that the putative archive works as expected. Because the atmospheric tritium production from bomb testing is well-documented, the archive will be subjected to a very rigorous test. The two products sought by the end of the proposed work are a) a methodology that can successfully liberate and measure the tritiogenic 3He in speleothems, and b) a confirmation or refutation of the key hypothesis of this proposal: Tritiogenic 3He preserved in water inclusions in speleothems can be measured and will change as a function of the concentration of tritium in local precipitation.

por.por_cntn:
Earth’s magnetic field shields both our planet and technological satellites from cosmic ray bombardment. While we know that the strength and orientation of the field changes over time, we do not know how fast these changes occur. For example, we do not know if the geomagnetic field strength can decrease to less than half of its modern-day strength within a human lifetime or if that change requires hundreds to thousands and years to occur. It is important to understand how fast such changes can occur given the vital function of the field in reducing cosmic ray bombardment to our technological infrastructure and biosphere. The only means of determining the potential rate of change is by investigating known geomagnetic changes that occurred in Earth’s past and that are recorded in the rock record. Here we investigated the use of a chemical signal as the indicator of geomagnetic field strength changes in the past. Cosmic rays that come largely from star forming processes in our galaxy, continually bombard Earth’s surface and atmosphere. When they collide with Earth’s surface and atmosphere, unique isotopes known as cosmogenic nuclides are generated. Consequently, when the field strength reduces, cosmic ray bombardment increases resulting in an increased rate of cosmogenic nuclide production. One of these cosmogenic nuclides is tritium (hydrogen-3) that decays to helium-3 with a half-life of approximately 12.3 years. As tritium this cosmogenic nuclide moves through the atmosphere and Earth’s crust as water where it can be captured and archived in cave deposits such as stalagmites and stalactites where it will ultimately decay to helium-3. This work focused on developing methods for analyzing tritium derived helium-3 in natural speleothem samples. Specifically, cave deposits that crystallized during the ‘bomb-pulse’ (increased nuclear bomb testing from ~1953-1963) are employed as a control as nuclear bombs also generated high amounts of atmospheric tritium.

We conducted various experiments measuring the helium isotopes from different cave deposits sampled and prepared in various ways. This allowed for the design of a crushing procedure of cave deposit material while under vacuum, which primarily releases the helium trapped in ancient water as opposed to the crystalline structure. We then collected a cave deposit that was determined to have grown through-out the nuclear bomb testing period and identified the portion of the deposit that grew during the bomb pulse using radiocarbon analysis. Ultimately, we took additional samples from the same portion of the bomb pulse aged cave deposit and analyzed the helium isotopes it contained using our new crushing method. Helium isotope measurements from samples of the cave deposit revealed an elevated abundance of helium-3 in the same portion of the cave deposit that showed elevated radiocarbon abundance. In contrast, the sample appeared to have normal levels of helium-3 pre- and post-ceding the bomb pulse layers. We conclude that helium-3 derived from tritium in the atmosphere is archived in cave deposit material over decades and may serve as a reliable proxy for geomagnetic field strength change through geologic time. The next step in this work is to conduct similar experiments on a section of cave deposit that was known to have formed during a geomagnetic anomaly associated with a large field strength reduction to determine if elevated helium-3 is present.

In addition to the scientific advancements of this work, this proposal supported the development of an early career researcher and helped build laboratory infrastructure for cave deposit sample preparation for helium analyses. The project also provided the basis for an undergraduate researcher thesis project that allowed the student to graduate and successfully get into a competitive graduate studies program.
